title: Verbal framing (temporal tense)
description: Participants who read what a person **was doing** (relative to those who read what person **did**) showed enhanced accessibility of intention-related concepts and attributed more intentionality to the person

title: Incidental environmental anchoring effect
description: incidental anchoring [[Critcher & Gilovich, 2008]](https://doi.org/10.1002/bdm.586), basic anchoring [[Wilson, Houston, Etling, & Brekke, 1996]](https://doi.org/10.1037//0096-3445.125.4.387) “Anchor values that are incidentally present in the environment can affect a person’s numerical estimates (...) these effects were not qualified by participants’ expertise in the relevant domain (study 1) or by their ability to subsequently recall the anchor value (study 3).” (Critcher & Gilovich, 2008

title: Scarcity effect - Wellbeing
description: Wellbeing. _**Imagining having less time available in one’s current city is positively associated with well-being.​

title: Scarcity effect - Opportunity costs
description: _Opportunity costs._** Poor people are more likely to consider opportunity costs spontaneously

title: Scarcity effect - Brand attitudes
status: replicated (NS); reported effects were not replicated, while a non-reported effect remained NS:

title: Scarcity effect - Preference for material goods
Structural brain-behaviour correlations - the association between distractibility and grey matter volume
